Situation1: Celebrate each other's achievements and milestones.
Expectation2: Provide initial medical care to patients
Situation2: The ambulance driver is responding to a patient with symptoms of a major heart attack
Story: Today was supposed to be all about my sister. She’d finally graduated after years of hard work, and our family had planned a surprise party. I promised her I’d be there, front and center, cheering the loudest. As I was getting ready, my radio crackled—an emergency call. A man nearby was having a major heart attack. I was the closest ambulance driver on shift. My training kicked in; I knew every second counted for him. But my phone buzzed with a message from my sister: “Can’t wait to see you! It won’t be the same without you.” My heart twisted. I could picture her scanning the crowd, hoping to see me, needing my support on her big day. But I also knew someone else’s family was counting on me to save their loved one. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each demanding my presence, each impossible to ignore. I sat frozen for a moment, torn between the siren’s call and my sister’s smile, feeling the impossible pull of being needed in two places at once.
